content.text: Sometimes you won't understand a specific word. It's perfectly okay to ask for clarification. Let's learn how.

data.tip: The Dutch 'ij' sounds a lot like the 'ey' in 'hey' or 'eye' in English.
The Dutch 'w' is soft, like a 'v'. The 'aa' is a long 'ah' sound, like in 'father'.

content.title: Seeking Clarification
content.setting: You've asked a supermarket employee where the Gouda cheese is. They have just replied, but you don't understand a key word.

conversation_flow.title: Say you don't understand the word 'zuivel'
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: De Goudse kaas is bij de zuivel.

conversation_flow.title: Ask where that is
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Oh, zuivel is melk, kaas, en yoghurt.

content.text: The employee pointed vaguely. To ask for more specific help, it's polite to use 'Kunt u...' which means 'Can you...' (formal).

data.tip: Remember the 'ij' sound? It's the same as in 'begrijp'. It sounds like the English word 'eye'.

content.text: In Dutch, 'u' is the formal way to say 'you', which is great for talking to staff. 'Jij' is the informal version for friends.

content.title: Getting Better Directions
content.setting: The employee pointed vaguely. You need them to show you exactly where to go.

conversation_flow.title: Ask the employee to show you
Thank the employee
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ja, natuurlijk. Kom maar mee. Kijk, hier is alle kaas.

data.tip: The 'e' at the end is a schwa, like the 'a' in the English word 'sofa'.

content.text: Dutch Gouda cheese is often sold by age. 'Jong' (young) is soft and mild, 'belegen' (matured) is firmer, and 'oud' (old) is hard and sharp.

content.title: Asking for a Recommendation
content.setting: You are now in front of a wall of cheese. You want to know which one the employee recommends.

conversation_flow.title: Acknowledge the recommendation and say thanks
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: De belegen kaas is erg lekker. Niet te jong, niet te oud.
